reviewText:
A few years ago I had a lot of fun with this game.  Not sure if it's still alive/active or whatever and I can't exactly find out since my account is just, I don't know, gone?  It's weird.

It was really fun, though.  Like a lot of games that have an overall account level, though, it wasn't the most balanced.  Later upgrades and planes were just, you know, objectively better than starting things.  The ships aren't necessarily rock-paper-scissors in design but there are elements like that to them.  Having said that, the starting ship is probably the best one, which is good for beginners.

Regardless, the ships were balanced enough that you could play whatever and probably be fine in most situations.  The game modes were varied enough.  You had death match and team death match, yeah, but there was also a mode where you destroyed an enemy base, and another where you effectively played soccor with the space ships.  I really liked the last one, but they were all fun and I'd play whatever when I did.

Controls were fine, graphics were fine, sounds were fine.  The only problem I ever encountered were some latency issues, where people would just appear to teleport somewhere else or where you were clearly disconnecting (everyone was falling or flying into walls).

Yeah, every now and then I boot this up and try to figure out my old account, or to make my old account work, but it never happens.  Had a lot of good times and I would totally play some more, if not a lot, should I ever fix that.  Good game, if you see it on sale, do check it out.  Assuming it's still alive.  It might not be!

The edit: game is mostly dead except for old elitists, apparently.  Shame.  Guess they are a pretty closed off community and not friendly to newbs.  Oh well.  RIP altitude.

reviewText:
If you like small short time 2D games, this is the right choice for you:

Being in a comic like 2D world, that reminds a little bit of worms, you control one of five fighter planes with each different playstyle and abilitys.
Armed with MGs, Rockets, Lasers and Bombs, you have to shoot down the enemys and survive as long as you can.
The game gives you a leveling system, achievments and with that the ability to customize your choose of abilitys you use.
Ingame you not only fly an shoot but have basic physical elements like altitude, speed and afterburner. If you get to slow while flying up, your engine will stall and you will fall from the sky. Also you can find one use weapons on the map, that will give you rockets, EMP fields and shields.

The game has a lot of game modes like Deathmatch, Team Deathmatch, last man standing and some form of capture the ball mode.

Even if it hasnt that big community anymore it still has usable full functional bots, which arent that big challenge, but still decent and dangerous.

Being able to be played with only the mouse, it is a nice game on mobile devices and a short game for long traveling.

reviewText:
Altitude is an online multiplayer dogfighting arcade game. You control cartoonish planes in various gametypes, which feature the standards you've come to expect: deathmatch, CTF, etc. There are a few spins on that, like Airball which plays much like a soccer game with shooting.

You start off with a basic plane, and can unlock more through leveling up. You level up by completing objectives in the games, or finishing matches. The gameplay is simple enough to learn, can control with a keyboard or gamepad, and features a tutorial to teach you about all the game typles. The visuals are very cartoonish, which match the arcade playstyle. This is by no means a simulation. The planes do not control realistically at all, so don't expect that.

Since this is a multiplayer game, you will have to rely on other people actually being online playing this game. On the occassions I've tried, there only seems to be one-two populated servers at any given time. You can play offline with bots, but that always takes some of the fun away from a multiplayer game. Plus, the bots don't really play like human opponents anyway.

Because of the lack of community (which frankly can be expected from a game a few years old without a really great hook), I do not recommend buying Altitude at this time. While it is fun enough in short spurts, you'll have to rely on there being available servers, which is not a guarantee at this time. Try it out if you already own it, but the pricetag is too high for newcomers.

Grade: C

Absolutely incredible indie game! With fast-paced, in-your-face action, Altitude keeps you on the edge of your seat. As you play, unlock a collection of five planes, along with an array of buffs, letting you customize your fighter to your personal style of play (via a perk system like Modern Warfare's). Pack in several game modes as well as a sizable collection of maps, and this indie title gives you variety that'll keep you coming back for more!\n\nReminiscent of an old-school DOS game I used to play on my 386, Altitude brings back memories. The keyboard controls are as simple as in the good ol' days, but you can also control your plane entirely with the mouse. Instead of the black-and-white pixels of my memories, the graphics are simple, sleek, crisp, and stylized like Team Fortress 2's, giving Altitude a longer future than games that aim for ultra-realism. Games don't need much realism; they need the simple elegance that Altitude has, with it's solid gameplay and balanced variety.

Altitude's simple premise hides behind a deceptively difficult game, but one that's easily learned and enjoyable to engage in. Although there's plenty of content here, more might have been better, but what is here does last, just so long as it's taken in the right doses.

reviewText:
Altitude is a fun little side-scrolling arena game that still has a dedicated competitive community today. Think Soldat with planes.

Easy and simple to play, however most servers are level restricted, which means you won't be able to play with your starter planes until you level up and unlock the more advanced ones.

The good news is you can create your own games and play against bots, which achieves the same thing as if you were playing against human opponents.

Unlocks provide new weapons, tools and abilities for your various planes, and usually provide different options, rather than straight 'upgrades'. This means that beginners can easily stand toe-to-toe with hardcore veterens.

Various modes are available, such as a soccer-like team game, and good old deathmatch.

It's not my cup of tea, but one of the better indie releases out there.
